messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> Really, I don't see my proposal as that radical. Right now we talk about
> #34 and give it a name. Presumably, we all have the same exact sound in
> our mind.

Actually, we don't. Let me take a far less controversial example,
one where splits and mergers aren't relevant, just pronunciation: the
opposition between #26 Busy and #27 Even. All dialects of English make
this distinction, and it is fundamental: there are hundreds of minimal
pairs like sit/seat and fit/feet. (There are a few dialects where
feet and feat are not pronounced the same, but let's ignore them for
the moment.)

Now in most of the U.K. and North America, this distinction is one of
quality: IPA /I/ vs. IPA /i/. In some dialects, though, the distinction
is one of quantity: IPA /i/ vs. IPA /i:/, where the colon indicates
a prolonged sound. Now if we do what you want and assign #26 to /I/
and #27 to /i/, then people who have such accents won't use #26 at all
and will have to write all of sit, seat, fit, feet, and feat with #27,
thus failing to make a very basic distinction.

But if we abandon the idea that QS letters correspond to particular
sounds and understand them to refer to particular phonemic oppositions
(a more abstract view), then everyone can use #26 for sit and fit and
#27 for seat and feet and feat with no worries.

> If we went to a coffee house and listened carefully for
> several hours, we should all be able to point out what words, when
> spoken, contained #34.

It's not so easy to discriminate IPA sounds by ear: one's native dialect
is constantly interfering. Australians often believe that people from
New Zealand use IPA /V/ (as in "strut") in "fish and chips", caricaturing
it as "fush and chups", but they don't: the vowel is actually a schwa.

> So why shouldn't we agree to a mapping that identifies it
> precisely rather than using the broken method of saying "well, it sounds
> like x?"

Because what that tells you is that you should use the sound used in
that word in your locality, whatever it may be.

--
